unnormalised: ## Choking on Progress: A Look at Air Quality in India
normalised: ## Choking on Progress: A Look at Air Quality in India

unnormalised: Hey everyone! Let's talk about something we're all breathing in, whether we like it or not: Air quality. Specifically, air quality here in India. And let’s be honest, the picture isn't always pretty, is it?
normalised: Hey everyone! Let's talk about something we're all breathing in, whether we like it or not: Air quality. Specifically, air quality here in India. And let's be honest, the picture isn't always pretty, is it?

unnormalised: We’ve all seen the smog hanging over Delhi during Diwali, right? Or read those scary headlines about kids in Mumbai developing respiratory problems at an alarming rate. It hits close to home. I remember visiting my cousin, Priya, in Ghaziabad last November. The air was so thick, you could practically taste it. They said the AQI was hovering around 450 at 10:00 hrs - officially “hazardous.” Made me think twice about taking that morning walk!

They said the A Q I was hovering around four hundred and fifty at ten o'clock hours - officially “hazardous.” Made me think twice about taking that morning walk!

unnormalised: A big contributor, of course, is vehicular pollution. All those cars, bikes, and auto-rickshaws chugging along, especially in cities like Bangalore, spew out a cocktail of pollutants. Construction dust is another major offender – ever tried navigating a Delhi Metro construction site at 14:30 on a dusty afternoon? Good luck with that!

unnormalised: But it’s not just the big cities. Even smaller towns are facing increased air pollution due to industrial emissions and burning of agricultural waste. Remember the news about farmers in Punjab and Haryana burning stubble after the harvest on 15/08/2023? That smoke travels, folks. It blankets the entire region.

unnormalised: So, what can we do? Well, the government is trying, with initiatives like the National Clean Air Programme and promoting electric vehicles. Institutions like IIT Delhi are also working on innovative solutions to monitor and mitigate pollution. But it takes more than just government action. We all have a role to play. Carpooling, using public transport, planting trees (think of the banyan trees our grandfathers planted!), and supporting sustainable practices are all steps in the right direction.

unnormalised: Because at the end of the day, clean air isn't just a luxury, it's a necessity. Let's work together to make sure future generations can breathe easy in our beautiful Bharat. Let's aim for a breathable India by 2030. What say?
